response:
네, 졸업논문을 체계적으로 준비하는 기본 흐름을 다시 정리해 드릴게요. 필요하면 학과나 분야에 맞춘 맞춤 플랜도 만들어 드립니다.

1) 주제 확정과 연구질문
- 관심 분야를 2~3개로 좁히고, 자료 가능성을 확인.
- 검증 가능한 연구질문(또는 가설) 하나를 명확히 설정.
- 주제의 학술적 기여와 실행 가능성을 간단히 정리.

2) 문헌고찰 계획
- 핵심 키워드 목록 만들기.
- 학술 데이터베이스에서 선행 연구 수집(학과 소속 데이터베이스, Google Scholar 등).
- 선행 연구의 이론/결과를 요약표로 정리하고, 연구 갭과 본인의 기여 포인트 파악.

3) 연구 설계/방법 결정
- 연구 설계 유형 선택(실험/설문/사례연구/데이터분석/문헌연구 등).
- 대상/샘플 크기, 자료 수집 도구 결정.
- 분석 방법 명시(통계분석, 질적 분석, 내용분석 등) 및 윤리 고려(필요 시 IRB 여부 확인).

4) 논문 구조 구성
- 일반적 목차 예시: 서론, 이론적 배경/문헌고찰, 방법, 결과, 논의, 결론, 참고문헌, 부록.
- 학과/기관의 양식에 맞춰 형식을 먼저 확인하고 초안 구성.

5) 글쓰기 프로세스
- 개요(outline) 작성: 각 장의 목표를 한두 문장으로 정리.
- 초안은 흐름에 집중(서론→문헌고찰→방법→결과→논의 순으로 핵심 포인트 먼저).
- 피드백 루프를 설정해 주기적으로 반영.
- 편집 순서: 내용·논리 → 문장 다듬기 → 표/그림 및 형식 확인 → 최종 교정.

6) 형식과 인용 관리
- 소속 학과의 참고문헌 스타일 확인(예: APA, MLA, Chicago, IEEE 등).
- 참고문헌 관리도구 사용 권장(Zotero/Mendeley/EndNote).
- 표/그림의 번호 매기기, 캡션 작성, 삽입 위치의 일관성 유지.

7) 작성 팁
- 명료하고 간결하게—핵심 메시지를 먼저 제시.
- 수치와 그림은 독립적으로 이해되도록 구성.
- 주장에 필요한 데이터와 근거를 항상 제시.
- 표절 방지와 인용 정확성 확보.

8) 시간 관리와 일정 예시
- 전체 기간 보통 2~6개월이나, 학과 일정에 맞춰 실제로는 8주 단위로 나누기 좋습니다.
- 예시(6주 기준):
  - 1주차: 주제 확정, 연구질문 확정, 지도교수와 초기 상담
  - 2주차: 문헌고찰 시작, 핵심 이슈 정리
  - 3주차: 연구방법 확정, 데이터 수집 계획 수립
  - 4주차: 자료 수집/정리 시작
  - 5주차: 초안 1차 작성(서론, 이론적 배경, 방법)
  - 6주차: 초안 2차 작성(결과/논의), 피드백 반영
  - 이후: 수정·보완, 최종 교정, 제출

9) 자주 하는 실수 피하기
- 모호한 주제나 연구질문으로 시작  
- 데이터 수집 계획이 불충분하거나 실행 불가  
- 형식/인용 규칙을 초기에 확정하지 않아서 수정 부담 증가  
- 지도교수와의 소통 부족으로 방향성 이탈

10) 체크리스트 요약
- 연구질문 확정
- 선행연구 충분히 수집/정리
- 방법 구체화 및 재현 가능성 확보
- 데이터 수집/분석 계획 구체화
- 초안 작성 → 피드백 반영 → 재작성
- 형식/인용 규정 준수
- 최종 검토(문법/오탈자/일관성) 후 제출

원하시면 학과나 분야에 맞춘 구체적인 맞춤 플랜도 만들어 드릴게요. 현재 주제 아이디어나 지금 가진 데이터 여부, 제출 마감일, 지도교수의 요구사항 등을 알려주시면 바로 맞춤형 일정과 구조를 제안해 드리겠습니다.
reference: 공주대 대학원 지침에 따라 논문은 간단·명료하게 작성하며, 제목(국·영문), 목차와 표·그림목차(별지), 본문, 인용문헌, 참고문헌, 초록, 부록의 순으로 구성한다. 본문 전개는 계열별 예시(인문사회/자연공학/예체능)를 따르고, 인용은 ‘저자(연도:쪽)’ 표기, 참고문헌은 규정된 서지 형식과 배열 순서를 따른다. 초록은 A4 1~2매로 국문 논문은 영문초록, 외국문 논문은 국문초록을 첨부한다.

response:
다음은 졸업논문 편집·인쇄의 핵심 포인트만 요약한 체크리스트입니다.

- 흐름과 구성 점검
  - 서론-문헌고찰-방법-결과-논의 순서가 논리적으로 연결되는지 확인.
  - 각 장의 목표가 한두 문장으로 명확히 드러나도록 개요를 점검.

- 언어·문체
  - 격식 있는 학술 톤으로 간결하게 다듬기. 모호한 표현·중복 제거.
  - 용어의 일관성 유지(약어 정의 후 전체에서 동일하게 사용).

- 형식·양식
  - 학과/기관의 양식(목차, 제목 수준, 표기 방식, 글꼴/줄 간격, 여백) 준수.
  - 표/그림의 번호 매김, 캡션 형식 일관성 유지.

- 인용·참고문헌
  - 선택한 인용 스타일(A..., MLA, Chicago, IEEE 등)로 일관성 있게 적용.
  - 본문 내 인용과 참고문헌 목록의 항목 매칭 확인.
  - DOI/URL 등 접근 가능한 정보 포함 여부 점검.
  - 참고문헌 관리도구(Zotero/Mendeley/EndNote)로 자동 정렬 가능 여부 확인.

- 표·그림 관리
  - 해상도 300dpi 이상, 필요 시 색상 구분은 흑백 호환성 고려.
  - 표/그림에 명확한 제목과 축/단위 표기.
  - 본문에서 표/그림을 처음 언급하는 위치와 순서를 확인.

- 데이터·윤리
  - 데이터 출처 명시, 비식별화 여부 확인.
  - 인간대상 연구인 경우 IRB 여부와 동의 절차 반영 여부 점검.

- 초안 검토 및 피드백 반영
  - 동료/지도교수 피드백 반영 여부를 확인하고 수정 기록 남기기.

- 최종 검토 항목
  - 맞춤법/띄어쓰기, 숫자 표기, 약자 풀어쓰기, 일관된 용어 사용.
  - 오탈자 및 문맥상 어색한 문장 다듬기.
  - 모든 그림/표의 위치가 흐름상 합리적인지 확인.

- 인쇄용 파일 준비
  - 최종본은 PDF로 저장, 글꼴 임베드 및 페이지 서식 고정.
  - 인쇄 시 필요한 경우 컬러 여부와 흑백 출력 고려, 바인딩 방식에 맞는 여백 조정.
  - 파일 이름 규칙 정리(예: 학과년도_논문제목_버전.pdf).

- 제출 준비
  - 초록(또는 요약)에서 연구질문과 주요 결과를 명확히 제시.
  - 제출 마감일, 제출 경로, 필요 서류(표지/서명란 등) 확인.

필요하면 학과 양식에 맞춘 구체적인 편집 템플릿이나 1페이지짜리 최종 체크리스트도 만들어 드릴게요. 학과명, 양식 규정, 제출 마감일 등 알려주면 바로 적용해 드립니다.
reference: 심사위원회 최종 통과 후 1개월 이내 인쇄 제출. 판종 4×6배판(19×26cm), 표지는 흑색 하드 양장 은박(박사는 금박), 본문지 약 80파운드 모조지, 글자 크기(장15/절13/소제목12/본문10~11/주10pt), 편집용지 B5(182×257mm), 줄간격 170~180%, 여백(위2.5/왼2.7/오른1.5/아래3cm), 본문 판면은 별지 양식, 단면 또는 양면 인쇄 가능.

response:
다음은 일반적인 졸업논문 제본 순서예요. 학교·학과의 제본 규정을 먼저 확인하는 게 좋습니다.

일반적 제본 순서
- 0) 규정 확인
  - 표지/속지 구성, 제본 방식(와이어, 스프링, 무선제본 등), 여백, 색상, 폰트 등 학교 지침 확인.

- 1) 최종 원고 및 출력물 준비
  - 본문과 부록까지의 페이지 순서가 확정된 PDF final 파일 확보.
  - 표지(front cover), 속지(inner cover), 목차, 리스트(그림/표), 용어집 등 필요한 모든 페이지의 순서를 재확인.

- 2) 표지/속지 디자인 확인
  - 표지에 들어갈 제목,Author, 학과, 제출연월 등 정보가 정확한지 확인.
  - 표지 재질(두께)과 색상, 로고 포함 여부 등 규정에 맞춘 디자인 확정.

- 3) 인쇄 준비
  - 본문은 종이 무게/용지 종류에 맞춰 양면인지 단면인지 결정.
  - 표지/속지는 더 두꺼운 종이를 사용 여부 결정.
  - 모든 페이지에 글꼴이 임베드되어 있는지 확인.

- 4) 실제 인쇄 및 다듬기
  - 페이지 순서에 맞춰 인쇄 후 오려내야 할 경우 정확히 절단.
  - 인쇄물의 끝처리(오탈자 수정 여부) 최종 점검.

- 5) 제본 방식에 따른 바인딩
  - 스프링/와이어 바인딩: 구멍 뚫기 → 링 삽입 → 정렬 및 고정.
  - 무선제본(핀/필름 제본 등): 제본사에 의뢰하거나 가정용 제본기로 처리.
  - 하드커버/소프트커버: 표지 커버 부착 및 내지 정렬 후 커버와 합체.
  주의점: 제본 시 페이지의 순서가 흐트러지지 않도록 최종 정렬 재확인.

- 6) 최종 품질 점검 및 제출용 준비
  - 표지/속지의 접합 상태, 표/그림 캡션 번호, 목차의 페이지 번호 일치 여부 확인.
  - 제출용으로 PDF 최종본, 물리본(제본본) 모두 필요한 경우 각각 점검.
  - 파일명 규칙(예: 학과년도_논문제목_버전.pdf)도 확인.

- 7) 제출
  - 물리본 제본본 제출 장소/수량 확인.
  - 제출일, 제출 경로(학과 사무실, 도서관 등) 확인.

제본 방식별 간단 팁
- 스프링/와이어 바인딩: 두께가 얇을 때 적합. 페이지가 잘 펴지도록 여백과 구멍 위치를 맞춰야 함.
- 무선제본: 깔끔한 외관이지만 두께에 따라 강도가 약해질 수 있음. 표지 고정력 확인 필요.
- 하드커버/소프트커버: 공식적이고 내구성이 좋지만 비용이 증가. 커버에 로고나 학교명 포함 여부 확인.

필요하면 학과명/제본 규정, 예상 페이지 수, 원하는 제본 방식에 맞춰 자세한 순서표와 체크리스트를 맞춤형으로 만들어 드릴게요.
reference: 제본 순서는 ①겉표지(별지1) ②백지 1장 ③논문제출지(별지2) ④인준지(석사·박사 별지3/4) ⑤본문(별지5) ⑥초록(국문 논문은 영문초록 별지6, 외국문 논문은 국문초록 별지10) ⑦부록(있을 경우)이다.

user_input: 도서관에 제출할 인쇄본은 몇 부야? 어디에 제출해?
response:
학과나 대학원별로 규정이 다르니 정확한 부수와 제출처는 소속 기관의 안내를 먼저 확인하는 게 가장 좋습니다. 아래은 일반적으로 참고할 만한 가이드와 확인 방법입니다.

- 보통 필요한 인쇄본 부수(참고용 범위)
  - 도서관 제출용 인쇄본: 보통 1~2부 정도를 요구하는 학교가 많습니다.
  - 학과/지도교수 보관용: 1부 정도를 추가로 요구하는 경우가 흔합니다.
  - 필요 시 심사위원용, 도서관 미소장용 등으로 추가 부를 더 요구하기도 합니다.
  => 총 3~4부 이상이 필요한 경우가 일반적이지만, 학교마다 다르니 반드시 확인하세요.

- 어디에 제출하나
  - 도서관 제본/제출 창구 또는 도서관 행정실/제출 안내 페이지
  - 대학원 행정실 또는 학과 사무실
  - 심사위원회나 학과지정 제출처가 있다면 그 곳으로도 보내야 할 수 있습니다
  => 제출처는 학교/학과의 공식 안내를 우선 확인하세요.

- 제출 전 확인 포인트
  - 표지/속지 구성, 제본 방식(하드커버, 소프트커버, 무선제본 등) 및 여백 규정 준수 여부
  - 각 부의 표지에 들어가는 정보(제목, 저자명, 학과명, 제출연월 등) 정확성
  - 글꼴 임베딩, 페이지 순서, 목차 번호의 일관성
  - 필요 서류(제출 확인서, 표지 서명란 등) 구비 여부
  - 전자 원문 제출 요건 여부도 함께 확인

원하시면 소속 대학의 학과/전공명을 알려주세요. 그에 맞춘 정확한 부수, 제출처, 제출 마감일 등 구체적인 안내를 바로 드리겠습니다.
reference: 인쇄본은 인준날인 원본 1부를 포함하여 총 3부를 제출하며, 제출장소는 중앙도서관 3층 학술정보과이다.

response:
도서관 전자 제출(원문 파일) 방법은 학교마다 조금씩 다르지만, 일반적으로 아래와 같이 진행합니다. 소속 대학의 공식 안내를 반드시 먼저 확인하는 게 가장 정확합니다.

1) 준비물 확인
- 최종 PDF 원문 파일: 본문(필수 부록 포함) 전체가 하나의 PDF로 정리되어 있어야 함.
- 필요 시 추가 파일 여부 확인: 예를 들어 표지 제출용 스캔본, 심사위원용 파일, 부록 데이터 파일 등.
- 메타데이터 입력 정보: 제목, 저자명, 학과/전공, 학위, 제출연월, 학번 등.
- 윤리/저작권 관련 서류: IRB 여부나 윤리 승인 문서가 요구되면 함께 준비.

2) 파일 형식 및 품질 요건
- 파일 형식: 보통 PDF로 제출. 일부 기관은 PDF/A나 특정 버전의 PDF를 요구하기도 함.
- 글꼴 임베딩: 글꼴이 반드시 포함되도록 설정.
- 페이지 구성: 표지/속지 포함 여부, 목차/목록의 페이지 넘김이 정확한지 확인.
- 해상도 및 품질: 그림/도표는 일반적으로 300dpi 이상 권장.
- 파일 크기 및 보안: 비밀번호 설정 금지 unless 필요한 경우만. 너무 큰 파일은 압축이나 해상도 조정으로 최적화.

3) 파일 이름과 메타데이터 예시
- 파일명 예시: 학번_학과_논문제목.pdf
  예) 20250001_컴공_딥러닝을_이용한_이미지_분류_논문.pdf
- 메타데이터 입력 예시: 제목, 저자, 학과, 학위, 제출연월, 키워드 등 학교 시스템이 요구하는 형식에 맞춰 입력.

4) 업로드 절차 (일반적인 흐름)
- 대학원 행정실/도서관의 전자제출 포털에 로그인.
- 전자제출 메뉴에서 논문/학위논문 제출 선택.
- 최종 PDF 원문 파일 업로드.
- 필요 시 추가 파일 업로드(표지 스캔본, 데이터 파일 등).
- 메타데이터 입력 및 확인.
- 제출 확인서/수신증 발급 여부 확인 후 제출 완료.
- 제출 마감일과 제출 경로(도서관 전자제출, 학과 사무실 등)가 정확한지 재확인.

5) 제출 후 점검 포인트
- 전자본과 물리본의 내용/페이지 순서가 일치하는지 재확인.
- 표지 정보(제목/저자/학과/제출연월)가 정확한지 확인.
- 전자 제출 시스템으로 발급된 확인증이나 접수번호를 보관.
- 필요 시 전자 원문 파일의 백업본 보관.

6) 자주 필요한 추가 안내
- 전자 제출 여부를 반드시 확인: 전자 원문 제출이 필요한지, 어떤 형식으로 어떤 파일이 필요한지 등은 학교별로 다릅니다.
- 제출 마감일 확인: 시점에 맞춰 업로드 및 최종 확인을 마치도록 여유 시간을 남겨 두기.
- 이후 인쇄본 제출 여부: 보통 도서관 제출용 인쇄본도 필요한 경우가 많으니, 전자 제출과 함께 인쇄본 제출 규정도 함께 확인.

필요하시다면 소속 대학의 학과/전공명, 주제 아이디어, 제출 마감일 등을 알려주시면 해당 기관의 구체적인 전자 제출 규정에 맞춘 맞춤형 절차와 파일 명명 규칙, 체크리스트를 바로 정리해 드리겠습니다.
reference: 도서관 홈페이지(연구·학습지원→학위논문제출) 또는 dCollection에서 온라인으로 원문파일을 제출하며, 제출 방법은 도서관 공고 및 dCollection 안내를 따른다.

user_input: 학위논문 공개는 원칙적으로 어떻게 돼? 비공개 가능해?
response:
대체로 학위논문은 도서관의 저장소에 공개 접근 가능하도록 업로드되지만, 학교마다 예외 규정이 있습니다. 핵심은 아래와 같습니다.

- 원칙: 대부분의 대학은 학위논문을 공개 저장소에 올려 검색 가능하게 만듭니다. 이는 학위 정보, 초록, 본문 일부 등을 포함할 수 있습니다.
- 비공개/임시 공개(에임보로): 연구 데이터의 민감성이나 상업적 가치, 특허 문제 등으로 일정 기간 비공개를 허용하는 경우가 많습니다. 이를 Embargo(임보)라고 부릅니다.
- 임보 기간: 일반적으로 6개월, 1년, 2년 등 다양한 기간을 선택할 수 있으며, 필요 시 연장 가능 여부가 기관 정책에 따라 다릅니다.
- 전면 vs 부분 공개: 기관에 따라 전면 공개를 기본으로 하되, 일부 부분(예: 본문 전체 대신 초록/목차만 공개) 또는 전면 비공개를 허용하는 경우가 있습니다. 다만 전면 비공개는 흔치 않고, 정책상 불가한 경우도 있습니다.
- 절차: 보통 졸업논문 제출 시 임보 여부를 함께 신청하고, 사유를 명시해야 하며 IRB/저작권 등 관련 요건 확인이 필요합니다.
- 주의점: 임보를 설정하더라도 물리본 제출이나 메타데이터는 규정에 맞춰야 하며, 전자 원문 제출 시 노출 범위가 임보에 맞게 적용되는지 확인이 필요합니다.

다음 단계 제안
- 소속 대학의 학과/대학원 행정실이나 도서관 안내 페이지에서 논문 공개 정책과 임보 가능 여부를 확인하세요.
- 가능하다면 임보 기간을 어떤 기간으로 설정할지, 어떤 부분을 비공개로 할지(전체/일부)를 결정하고 신청서를 제출합니다.
- 필요 시 지도교수와 상의해 임보 사유를 구체적으로 명시하고, 저작권/데이터 보안 관련 서류를 준비합니다.
- 정확한 정책은 소속 기관에 따라 다르므로, 학교/학과 이름을 알려주시면 해당 기관의 구체적 규정과 절차를 바로 안내해 드리겠습니다.

원하시면 특정 대학의 정책을 확인해 맞춤형 안내나 임보 신청 샘플 문서를 만들어 드리겠습니다. 대학명과 학과를 알려주세요.
reference: 학위논문은 원칙적으로 공개하며, 특별히 비공개할 사유가 있는 경우 학위논문 저작권 비동의 사유서를 첨부하여 비공개를 신청할 수 있다.

user_input: How can I extend my visa in Korea?
response:
Yes. If you’re in Korea on a student visa (usually D-2) you can extend your stay by applying for a visa extension with the immigration office (HiKorea). Here’s a concise guide to get you started, plus tips to customize it to your situation.

What to do (overview)
1) Check the expiration date and apply early
- Start the process well before your current permission to stay expires (ideally 1–2 months in advance; many offices accept up to 3 months before expiry).

2) Get help from your university
- Visit your International Student Office or the graduate school admin. They can confirm the exact documents you need and may help with enrollment/status proofs.

3) Gather documents (typical for D-2 extension)
- Passport and current Alien Registration Card (ARC) or stay permit details.
- Completed extension application form (available on HiKorea or at the immigration office).
- Certificate of Enrollment (재학증명서) showing you are currently enrolled.
- Transcript or progress report for the current term.
- Financial evidence (e.g., bank statements, scholarship/tuition sponsorship) showing you can support yourself during extended stay.
- School-related documents if required (e.g., study plan, supervisor’s letter, research progress for thesis students).
- Passport-sized photo (if required by the office).
- Any IRB/ethics approvals or other documents your university or sponsor requires.
- Processing fee (amount varies by visa type; expect around several tens of thousands of KRW).

4) Submit the application
- You can usually submit online via HiKorea or at a local Immigration Office. Some universities offer a submission coordination service.
- Ensure your current status is valid through the submission date.

5) After submission
- You may be asked for an interview or to provide additional documents.
- Processing times vary (often days to a few weeks). Do not travel outside Korea while a renewal is pending unless the office says it’s allowed.

6) Receive your extended permission
- If approved, you’ll get a new stay period and, typically, a new stamp or updated ARC-details. Some offices issue a new digital record rather than a sticker.

Tips and notes
- Always confirm exact requirements with HiKorea and your university because documents and fees can vary by applicant situation and changes in policy.
- If you plan to work while studying or change status later, ask your international office what options are allowed under your extension.
- Avoid overstay. If renewal seems unlikely before expiry, contact the immigration office or your university ASAP to discuss a possible temporary extension or other options.
- Keep copies of all documents and the confirmation/receipt from the immigration system.

If you share a few specifics, I can tailor a checklist and timeline for you:
- Your university and department
- Current visa type and expiration date
- Whether you’re still enrolled or finishing a degree (e.g., defending a thesis)
- Your financial sponsor and amount available
- Any special requirements from your advisor or department

Sources for official steps (recommended)
- HiKorea (Immigration information portal) and your local Immigration Office page
- Your university’s International Office or Graduate Office procedures

Would you like me to draft a personalized, step-by-step extension plan based on your exact details (university, deadline, and sponsor data)?
reference: You can apply from up to 3 months before your stay expires until the expiration date. For a general extension (undergraduate/graduate), prepare: application, passport copy, ARC, transcript, enrollment certificate, tuition payment receipt, proof of residence, the fee of 60,000 KRW, and financial proof of at least 8,000,000 KRW per year; if your last-semester GPA is below C/2.0, include a statement of reasons.

user_input: What documents do I need for the extension?
response:
Here are the common documents you’ll typically need to extend a student visa (D-2) in Korea. Exact requirements can vary by university and immigration office, so it’s best to confirm with your international student office and HiKorea.

Standard documents
- Passport and Alien Registration Card (ARC): originals and a copy of the photo page and current ARC details.
- Current visa/Stay permit information: proof of your current status and its expiration date.
- Completed extension application form: usually available on HiKorea or at the immigration office.
- Certificate of Enrollment (재학증명서) or official proof that you are enrolled and actively studying.
- Transcript or progress report for the current term: shows your academic standing and progress.
- Financial evidence: demonstrate you can support yourself during the extended stay.
  - Bank statements for the last 3–6 months
  - Scholarship award letter or sponsor letter (if applicable)
  - Official tuition/payment receipts or proof of funding
- Study-related documents (as applicable to thesis/research students)
  - Study plan or research plan outlining your current and planned activities
  - Supervisor’s letter confirming ongoing supervision and expected progress
- Research/ethics documents (if your work involves human subjects)
  - IRB approval or ethics clearance (if required by your project)
- Photographs: typically a passport-style photo meeting the office’s specifications (size may vary)
- Additional university documents (when requested)
  - Letter from department or supervisor confirming enrollment status and expected graduation/defense date
  - Any departmental forms or letters specific to your program
- Administrative / processing fees
  - Application fee (amount varies)

Electronic submission specifics (HiKorea/immigration portal)
- If you must submit electronically, ensure: PDFs with embedded fonts, images at suitable resolution (often 300 dpi for figures), and properly named files.
- File naming examples may be requested by the system (e.g., your student ID, department, and document type).
- Keep the submission receipt/confirmation number.

Optional or situation-specific items
- Proof of housing or accommodation (not always required, but may be asked in some cases)
- Proof of language study or program-specific requirements
- Letters of recommendation or extra faculty letters if requested by the university

Tips
- Start gathering documents early; aim to apply 1–2 months before your current permission expires (some offices accept up to 3 months prior).
- Coordinate with your university’s international office for exact requirements and any program-specific items.
- If an interview or additional documents are requested, respond promptly to avoid delays.
- After submission, monitor for any requests for corrections or supplementary documents.

If you share specific details (university/department, current status, funding, and your target extension date), I can customize this list into a tailored checklist and even draft templates for you.
reference: For a general extension: ① application ② passport copy ③ ARC ④ transcript ⑤ enrollment certificate ⑥ tuition payment receipt ⑦ proof of residence ⑧ fee 60,000 KRW ⑨ financial proof ≥ 8,000,000 KRW per year ⑩ statement of reasons if last-semester GPA < C/2.0.

user_input: How much is the extension fee?
response:
Fees for extending a student visa (D-2) in Korea are not fixed nationwide and can vary by office and submission method. Here’s what you can expect:

- Typical range: about 50,000 to 70,000 KRW for the extension application. Many offices standardize around 60,000 KRW.
- Online vs in-person: the basic extension fee is usually the same, but some online portals may add a small processing fee. Check the HiKorea portal for your district.
- Additional costs you might encounter: photo fees, translation or certification of documents, notarization, copies, or any university/agency handling fees if you use their service.

To get an exact amount for your case:
- Check the fee schedule on HiKorea for your local Immigration Office.
- Ask your university’s International Office or Graduate School admin for the precise amount and payment method.
- If you share your city/office and whether you’ll submit online or in person, I can give you a precise figure and a tailored checklist.
reference: The extension fee is 60,000 KRW. Government Scholarship (GKS) students are exempt only from the revenue stamp if they submit the scholarship certificate; other fees still apply as specified.

user_input: What are the financial requirements for an extension?
response:
Here’s what typically counts as the financial requirement for extending a student visa (D-2) in Korea. Exact amounts are set by HiKorea/immigration and your university, so use these as a guide and confirm with your international office.

What funds must cover
- Extended stay living expenses: rent, meals, transportation, utilities, books, personal costs, etc.
- Any remaining tuition and mandatory fees for the extended period (if not already paid).
- Funds should be readily accessible for the duration of the extension.

How much to show (method, not a fixed number)
- There is no universal minimum you must meet; offices assess based on your planned extension period and local living costs.
- A practical approach: estimate your extended period (e.g., 6 or 12 months) and calculate:
  - Estimated monthly living costs in your city and campus life
  - Add any upcoming tuition/fees for that period
  - Total = requested extension funds
- City/lifestyle matters: living costs in Seoul are typically higher than in smaller cities; adjust your estimate accordingly.
- If you have scholarships, stipends, or sponsor support, include the exact coverage amount and duration.

Documents to prove funds
- Bank statements: last 3–6 months, showing sufficient balance and steady transactions.
- Sponsor letter (if a family member or other person is funding you): include sponsor’s name, relationship to you, contact info, and confirmation of ongoing support; attach sponsor’s bank statements or income proof.
- Scholarship or grant letter: amount, duration, and what it covers (tuition, living costs, etc.).
- Tuition receipts or official funding letters indicating coverage for the extension period.
- Proof of readily accessible funds: readily withdrawable funds, not just long-term assets; if funds are in fixed deposits or investments, provide documents showing liquidity or an available withdrawal plan.
- Translations: if required, have documents translated into Korean or English (as specified by HiKorea/your university).
- Any additional university documents: department letters confirming continued enrollment and expected progress or extension needs.

Tips to strengthen your submission
- Use clearly labeled documents with amounts, dates, and currency.
- Show a stable funding source (consistent monthly deposits, sponsor income, or scholarship disbursement schedules).
- Explain any large one-time transfers or unusual transactions with a concise note.
- Ensure the official name on all documents matches your passport/ARC.
- Check whether your university’s international office has a preferred format or template (they often do).

Next steps
- If you share:
  - City or campus (Seoul, Busan, etc.)
  - University and department
  - Extension duration (six months, 12 months, etc.)
  - Funding sources (self-funded, scholarship, sponsor)
  - Any upcoming tuition or fees
I can tailor a precise funding amount target, a checklist, and ready-to-use templates (funds calculation sheet, sponsor/confirmation letters, and a sample financial support letter) for your situation.
reference: For a general extension, you need financial proof of at least 8,000,000 KRW per year. For completion extensions, the amount is calculated as (1,000,000 KRW × number of months to extend + tuition) × 0.5, e.g., 12 months → 8,000,000 KRW.

user_input: I’m a graduate student who already completed coursework. What should I prepare for extension?
response:
Here’s a tailored prep checklist for a graduate student who has already completed coursework and needs to extend to finish the degree (thesis/dissertation). It covers what to prepare for the visa extension (D-2) in Korea and how to present ongoing academic progress.

Core extension documents (what to submit to HiKorea/immigration)
- Passport and ARC copies (and a copy of your current visa page)
- Extension application form (HiKorea online or the local immigration office form)
- Certificate of enrollment or proof of ongoing status (재학증명서) showing your current program status and expected extension period
- Academic progress evidence:
  - Transcript or progress report showing coursework completed
  - Letter from your supervisor confirming continued supervision and the plan to complete the thesis during the extension
  - Department/Graduate School letter confirming that your degree requirements will be completed via thesis/research in the extended period
- Research plan and timeline for the extension period:
  - A concise research plan (research questions, methods, data collection/analysis) and a milestone calendar (e.g., draft chapters, data collection windows, defense date)
  - Any IRB or ethics approvals status if you will be collecting new data (include approval documents or exemption notice)
- Financial proof for the extension period:
  - Bank statements covering the past 3–6 months
  - Sponsor letter (if funded by family/sponsor) with attached sponsor bank statements or income proof
  - Scholarship/tuition support letters and details about coverage for living costs and tuition during the extension
  - If you have a departmental or university grant, include award letters and disbursement schedule
- Proof of readily accessible funds and fund timing:
  - Clear documentation showing funds are available when needed during the extension (avoid only long-term assets)
- Supporting documents for consistency and credibility:
  - Your name, passport number, and program details should match across all documents
  - If translations are required, include translated versions (Korean or English) as specified by HiKorea/university
- Photos and any standard forms required by your university or immigration office
- Electronic submission specifics (if applicable):
  - PDFs with proper file naming conventions
  - Confirmation or receipt numbers from electronic submission portals

Documents to demonstrate degree progress and planning
- Thesis progress documents:
  - Updated outline of chapters, current draft status, and expected submission date for the thesis
  - A short progress report (1–2 pages) summarizing completed work, remaining tasks, and anticipated milestones
- Supervisor and department support:
  - A formal letter from your supervisor confirming ongoing supervision, expected defense date (if known), and that the extension is necessary to complete the thesis
  - A department/graduate school letter endorsing the extension and confirming degree requirements under thesis/research completion
- Ethics and data management (if applicable):
  - IRB approval status or exemption, data management plan, and data access/usage details if you’re continuing data collection

Financial readiness for extension
- As there is no universal minimum you must meet, prepare a credible estimate of funds for the extension period:
  - Estimated living costs for the extended period (rent, meals, transportation, utilities, books, personal expenses)
  - Any remaining tuition and mandatory fees for the extension period
  - Documents showing funds will be available for the exact extension duration (monthly or periodic withdrawal/deposits)
- Organize documents clearly:
  - Label amounts, dates, currencies, and sources
  - Include a sponsor letter if applicable, with sponsor contact info and relationship to you

Additional tips
- Start early: aim to prepare and submit 1–2 months before your current status expires, allowing time for any requests or interviews.
- Coordinate with your international office and your graduate school—often they have preferred templates and checklists.
- Ensure consistency across documents (names, dates, program title, department) to avoid delays.
- Keep copies of everything and note submission receipt numbers or reference IDs.

Timeline and next steps
- Step 1: Gather existing documents (transcripts, enrollment proof, supervisor/department letters, any IRB docs).
- Step 2: Draft your research plan and extension milestone schedule.
- Step 3: Collect financial documents (bank statements, sponsor letters, scholarship letters).
- Step 4: Obtain formal letters from supervisor and department.
- Step 5: Complete the HiKorea/immigration extension application and attach all documents.
- Step 6: Submit, then monitor for any requests or interviews.

If you share some details, I can tailor this further and even draft templates:
- Your university, department, and city
- Expected extension duration (months)
- Status: have you begun writing already? Any defense date planned?
- Funding sources (self, scholarship, sponsor)
- Any IRB or data collection plans for the extension

Would you like me to generate:
- A ready-to-use research-plan and milestone timeline template for your extension
- A funding worksheet to estimate and present the required funds
- A supervisor/department support letter template and a progress update letter?
reference: For completion extension (bachelor/master/doctoral graduates): ① application ② passport copy ③ ARC ④ transcript ⑤ completion certificate ⑥ advisor confirmation ⑦ statement of reasons ⑧ proof of residence ⑨ financial proof for 6 months (typically 4,000,000 KRW by the stated formula) ⑩ fee 60,000 KRW.

user_input: What if my GPA is low?
response:
Short answer: a low GPA can complicate an extension, but it’s not necessarily a deal-breaker. What matters most for visa extension and degree completion is your demonstrated progress, a credible plan to finish, and strong support from your advisor and department.

What to do if your GPA is low

- Gather evidence of progress and support
  - Your current transcript showing recent grades and trend
  - A letter from your supervisor confirming ongoing supervision and your plan to finish the thesis during the extension
  - A department/graduate school letter endorsing the extension and outlining required degree milestones (e.g., defense date)
  - A clear research plan with milestones and a realistic timeline to completion
  - Any IRB approvals, data collection updates, and a status report of chapters drafted

- Address the GPA directly in your materials
  - Include a concise explanation for the low GPA (e.g., difficult semesters, health issues, heavy course load, more focus on research or data collection)
  - Emphasize what you’ve done to improve and what you will do to ensure timely completion (improved coursework, focused data collection, stronger dissertation progress)
  - Highlight evidence of turning point or improved trajectory (e.g., recent grades, completed chapters, defended drafts)

- Show a compelling plan to finish
  - A milestone-based timeline for the extension period (chapter drafts, data analysis, defense)
  - A plan for any remaining coursework or prerequisites, if needed, and how you’ll manage them alongside research
  - A realistic defense date and an outline of what will be submitted by each milestone

- Align with the university and immigration expectations
  - Have your international student office review your materials and confirm what the visa office expects
  - If appropriate, ask about conditional or milestone-based extensions tied to progress rather than a blunt GPA criterion
  - Ensure your financial documentation remains solid and reflects the extension period

- Optional: remedial steps you can take
  - If allowed by your program, plan to retake or upgrade specific courses to show recent improvement
  - Participate in additional research activities or writing/completion workshops to accelerate progress
  - Document any extenuating circumstances and provide evidence; show you’ve mitigated them

What a manager-friendly plan might look like

- GPA context note (brief): one-paragraph explanation of past issues and steps taken to address them.
- Progress summary: what has been completed (e.g., literature review draft, data collection in progress), what remains.
- Milestones and dates: chapter drafts due dates, data analysis milestones, draft defense date.
- Support letters: supervisor and department confirming continued supervision and the necessity of extending to finish.
- Risk management: potential bottlenecks and contingency plans (e.g., if data collection delays, how you’ll adjust the timeline).
- Financial readiness: funds for living and tuition during the extension period.

Templates you can consider

- GPA explanation letter (to the department/visa office): a brief, factual explanation plus a positive plan for finishing.
- Milestone timeline for extension: a month-by-month or 8-week-block plan with specific deliverables and dates.
- Supervisor support letter template: statements of ongoing supervision, expected defense date, and rationale for extension.
- Progress update letter: a 1–2 page summary of what’s done, what’s left, and how the extension enables completion.

Next steps I can help with

- If you share:
  - Your university, department, and city
  - Current status of your thesis (how much is drafted, what data you have)
  - Your expected extension duration and funding situation
  - Any IRB or data collection plans
  - A rough explanation of why GPA is low
I can tailor:
- A precise, ready-to-use GPA explanation letter
- A milestone-based extension plan with dates
- A supervisor/department support letter draft
- A concise one-page progress report template

Key takeaway: be proactive, transparent, and provide a credible plan showing you can finish within the extension period. Your advisor and department’s endorsement, plus a solid milestones-based plan, often carry more weight with visa and degree committees than GPA alone. If you share your details, I’ll draft the tailored templates and checklists you need.
reference: If your last semester GPA is below C/2.0, you must submit a statement of reasons when applying for a general extension.

user_input: I will advance to a higher degree at the same university. What do I need?
response:
Great question. Moving from your current degree to a higher degree at the same university typically means you’re aiming to switch from, for example, a Master’s to a PhD (or MS to PhD) within the same institution. The exact steps and required documents vary by university and program, but here’s a practical, comprehensive checklist and process to help you prepare.

1) Clarify the path
- Define the target degree and program clearly (e.g., Master’s to PhD in [department], or coursework-only Master’s to research-based Master’s, etc.).
- Check whether your university allows an internal transfer/change of program without a full new application, or if you must submit a formal internal transfer/application to the new program.
- Confirm deadlines and whether any qualifying exams, additional prerequisites, or a new thesis/research plan are required.

2) Visa and status considerations (Korea)
- Even if you stay at the same university, a change of degree or program often requires updates to your student status and possibly a visa status adjustment.
- Coordinate with:
  - Your university’s international student support office (and the graduate school/department)
  - HiKorea or the local Immigration Office (to verify if a new extension or status update is needed)
- Prepare to show continued enrollment and a credible plan to complete the new degree within the extended period.

3) Core documents you’ll likely need
- Official transcripts and degree certificates for your current program (and any degree awarded or in progress)
- Statement of purpose or intent letter for the new program
- Research plan or dissertation proposal aligned with the higher degree (outline, research questions, methods)
- Updated curriculum vitae
- Letters of recommendation (typically 2–3; from your supervisor and other faculty)
- Supervisor’s support letter confirming ongoing supervision and feasibility of completing the higher degree
- Department/Graduate School endorsement letter confirming the need and viability of the transition
- Evidence of progress toward degree completion (progress report, draft chapters, recent grades if applicable)
- IRB/ethics status and any data collection plans (if you’ll continue or begin new data collection)
- Any required standard forms for internal transfer/change of program
- Proof of funding for the extended period (funding letters, scholarship details, or bank statements if required)
- Language proficiency documents if the new program requires it (less common within the same university, but check)
- Consistency materials: ensure names, program titles, and student IDs match across all documents
- If translations are needed, include translated versions as required

4) Optional but highly valued: evidence to offset GPA concerns
- A clear milestone-based plan showing how you will finish the new degree within the extended period
- Letters from your advisor and department underscoring continued mentorship and the necessity of the transition
- A concise progress narrative: what you’ve completed (chapters, data, coursework) and what remains
- Any recent upward trend in performance or successful progress milestones

5) Suggested materials to prepare (templates you may want)
- Internal transfer/change of program request letter (from you)
- Research plan and milestone timeline for the new degree
- Supervisor support letter template (ongoing supervision and defense date or completion plan)
- Department/Graduate School endorsement letter template
- Progress report template (1–2 pages: completed work, remaining tasks, timeline)
- Financial readiness statement or funding confirmation letter

6) Proposed process and typical timeline
- Step 1: Meet with your current supervisor and the target program’s admissions/grad chair to confirm viability and requirements.
- Step 2: Gather and draft your application materials (SOP, research plan, CV, progress report).
- Step 3: Obtain letters of recommendation and the necessary endorsement letters from your supervisor and department.
- Step 4: Submit the internal transfer/change-of-program form or the formal application to the new program, depending on your university’s process.
- Step 5: If accepted, coordinate with international student services to update your visa/record (this may involve HiKorea/immigration steps).
- Step 6: Enroll in the new program, set up a milestone plan (defense date, chapters, exams) and begin the transition.
- Typical duration: 3–9 months for the internal transfer process, plus the time needed to complete the new degree after confirmation.

7) Quick questions to tailor next steps
- What is your current degree and department, and what is the target degree?
- Do you know whether your university requires an internal transfer vs. a full new application?
- Do you have a confirmed supervisor for the new program, and are they supportive?
- Do you have funding for the extended period, or will you need a new funding source?
- What is your current progress (thesis/draft status, completed coursework), and what’s your expected completion date with the higher degree?
- Are there visa deadlines or expiration dates you must meet soon?

8) I can tailor templates and a plan
If you share:
- University and department
- Current degree and program status
- Target degree and program
- Expected timeline and any known deadlines
- Funding situation and supervisor’s stance
I can draft:
- A focused internal transfer/change-of-program request letter
- A research plan and milestone timeline for the new degree
- A supervisor endorsement letter and a progress report template
- A concise visa/extension checklist aligned with HiKorea and your university

Tell me your specifics, and I’ll prepare ready-to-use templates and a concrete, step-by-step plan tailored to your situation.
reference: Prepare: ① application ② passport copy ③ ARC ④ transcript ⑤ enrollment certificate ⑥ tuition payment receipt ⑦ proof of residence ⑧ fee 60,000 KRW ⑨ standard admission letter ⑩ final academic documents (with official verification for overseas schools) ⑪ financial proof 16,000,000 KRW or, if advancing within the same university, 8,000,000 KRW.

user_input: When can I apply for a visa extension?
response:
Short answer: In Korea, you should apply for a visa extension before your current status expires. A practical window is roughly 1–2 months before expiration, up to about 3 months if possible. Start earlier if processing times or your university/immigration office require it, and always confirm the latest rules with HiKorea and your university’s international student office.

What to do now
- Check your ARC/visa expiration date and set a target date within the 1–3 month window before that date.
- Contact your university’s international student office (and your graduate school) to confirm exact extension requirements and deadlines.
- Gather supporting documents (typical list; confirm with your office):
  - Passport and current ARC
  - Certificate of Enrollment or proof you’re still enrolled
  - Current transcript and/or progress certificate
  - Financial documentation showing funds for the extended period
  - Research plan, milestones, and a letter from your supervisor endorsing the extension
  - Updated thesis/dissertation progress report or milestones
  - Any IRB/ethics approvals if continuing data collection
  - Recent passport-sized photo and the extension application form
- Submit through HiKorea online (or as advised by your local immigration office) and schedule any required in-person appointments.
- Plan for processing time and avoid travel during processing; have a contingency plan if the extension is not approved.
- If there are complications (e.g., GPA concerns or changes in status), work with the international office to explore conditional/milestone-based extensions or alternatives.

If you share your university, department, current program, and how long you need the extension, I can tailor a precise checklist, a timeline, and draft templates for your GPA explanation (if needed), supervisor support, and the extension plan.
reference: You may apply from 3 months before the expiry date up to the expiration day. Overstaying leads to fines.

user_input: I changed my address. What do I need to do?
response:
Short answer: In Korea, you should update your address with the immigration office (HiKorea), and also update your university records and any other institutions that have your address on file. Do this as soon as possible, ideally within 14 days of moving.

What to do now
- Update your immigration/ARC address
  - Go to HiKorea (online) or visit your local 출입국관리사무소 (Immigration Office).
  - Bring your passport, Alien Registration Card (ARC), new lease or housing contract, and proof of new residence (e.g., official utility bill or bank statement if required).
  - Expect to fill out a change of address form and possibly a short interview.
- Inform your university
  - Notify the International Student Support office and your department/graduate school about your new address.
  - Update your address in the student information system and confirm your emergency contact if needed.
- Update on-campus and housing records
  - If you live in campus housing or have a housing contract, provide the new address to the housing administrator.
- Update core services and records
  - Banks and financial accounts: update address for statements and needed verification.
  - National Health Insurance (NHIC) or other health coverage: ensure your address is current.
  - Mobile phone, internet, and other service providers: update billing and contact details.
  - Any scholarships or payroll/stipends: ensure they have the correct address.
- Update other important entities
  - Employer or internship supervisor, if applicable.
  - Any other institutions that require your mailing address (tax office, etc.).

Documentation you may need
- Proof of new residence (new lease, housing contract, or official utility bill in your name).
- Your ARC and passport.
- Any university forms for address change (if required by your campus).
- A brief note or email confirming your new address for departments and services.

Tips
- Do this proactively before any important mail or deadlines arrive.
- Keep copies of the submission receipts and any confirmation numbers.
- If you’re nearing your visa extension or status change, make sure your new address is reflected across all immigration-related documents to avoid delays.

If you share details like your university, department, new address, and your ARC number (optional), I can draft:
- a short change-of-address email to your International Office,
- a brief notice to the immigration office, and
- a checklist tailored to your situation.
reference: Report the change of address within 14 days to the local community center or immigration office. Prepare: application, passport copy, ARC, and proof of residence such as a lease, accommodation provider’s confirmation, or dormitory receipt.

user_input: How do I change my status to D-2 (student)?
response:
Short answer
To change your status to D-2 (degree student) you typically need to be admitted to a Korean university. You can apply either from inside Korea (change of status) or from outside Korea (apply for a D-2 visa at a Korean embassy/consulate). The exact path depends on your current status and your university’s policies.

Step-by-step guide

1) Confirm eligibility and secure admission
- Get your official admission letter or Certificate of Admission from the university.
- Ensure you have the program start date and estimated duration.

2) Decide where to apply
- If you are in Korea on a status that allows changing stay: you can apply for a change of status to D-2 at HiKorea online or at a local Immigration Office.
- If you cannot or prefer not to switch inside Korea: leave Korea (if required) and apply for a D-2 visa at a Korean embassy/consulate in your home country or current country of residence. You’ll enter Korea on a D-2 visa after visa issuance.

3) Gather required documents (typical list)
- Passport (valid for at least 6 months) and current ARC (if you are already in Korea)
- Change-of-status application form (입국관리사무소) or HiKorea online submission (inside Korea)
- Admission letter or Certificate of Enrollment from the university
- Official transcript and/or current progress report
- Proof of funds for tuition and living expenses (bank statements, scholarship letters, sponsor letters)
- Study plan or research plan (for the program/department)
- Letter from your supervisor or department endorsing the D-2 status
- Academic documents (diploma/certificates)
- Two recent passport photos
- Any program-specific documents (IRB approvals, ethics approvals, etc., if you’ll continue research)
- Application/visa fees (check exact amounts with HiKorea or the local office)

4) Submit your application
- Inside Korea: Submit the change-of-status request via HiKorea online or at the Immigration Office. Prepare for possible short interviews.
- Outside Korea: Submit your D-2 visa application at the Korean embassy/consulate with the same supporting documents. Your passport will be stamped with the D-2 visa.

5) Processing time and follow-up
- Processing typically ranges from about 4 to 12 weeks, depending on the office and case specifics.
- You may be asked for an interview or additional documents. Stay in close contact with your university’s International Office.

6) After approval
- Inside Korea: your status changes to D-2 and you’ll receive updated immigration records. You may need to visit the Immigration Office to update your ARC with the new status.
- Outside Korea: your passport will bear the D-2 visa. Enter Korea on that visa and then complete any in-country registration or ARC procedures as required.

Tips
- Coordinate with your university’s International Student Support Office and your department early to ensure you have the correct documents and deadlines.
- If you have any GPA concerns or other issues, discuss them with the International Office; they can advise on conditional/milestone-based options.
- Keep copies of all submissions and receipts, and track the status online if possible.

What I need to tailor this for you
- Are you currently inside or outside Korea, and what is your current visa status?
- Which university and department are you aiming for, and what program start date?
- Do you have proof of funds and a study plan ready?
- Any special circumstances (GPA issues, ongoing research, scholarship, etc.)?

If you share these details, I can draft a precise checklist, a timeline, and template documents (e.g., a request email to the International Office, a study-plan outline, and a sponsor/financial support letter) customized to your situation.
reference: Apply before the semester starts; changing status later than 30 days after graduation may incur a fine. Prepare: application, passport copy, ARC (if any), photo, standard admission letter, final academic documents (official verification if from overseas), tuition receipt, proof of residence, fee 135,000 KRW (exceptions: GKS students pay 35,000 KRW for ARC issuance; 60,000 KRW for same-university advancement), financial proof of at least 16,000,000 KRW—or 8,000,000 KRW if advancing within the same university—plus, if changing from D-4, a completion certificate that shows grades and attendance.
